This pattern is a still a stub.
For a more thorough examination of the concept of <style="CurrentLink">Togetherness</style> in the context of gaming, see Bergström 2012.
* Group solidarity, a feeling of membership
* Emotional energy in the individual: a feeling of confidence, elation, strength, enthusiasm, and initiative in taking action

* Symbols that represent the group: emblems or other representations (visual icons, words, gestures) that members feel are associated with themselves collectively; these are Durkheim’s “sacred objects”. Persons pumped up with feelings of group solidarity treat symbols with great respect and defend them against the disrespect of outsiders, and even more of renegade insiders.

* Feelings of morality: the sense of rightness in adhering to the group, respecting its symbols, and defending both against transgressors. Along with this goes the sense of moral evil or impropriety in violating the group’s solidarity and symbolic representations.

<style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> is a basic foundation for allowing <style="CurrentLink">Togetherness</style> to emerge. While engaging in actual gameplay activities with one another, e.g. in <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, is one form the pattern may take other possible forms can be that players together create a story (which can be represented by <style="Link"><link="game-instance-stories">Game Instance Stories</link></style>), that player shared misfortunes together (as described by <style="Link"><link="spectacular-failure-enjoyment">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</link></style>), and that period with little or no gameplay allowed players to socialize without performing gameplay actions (i.e., interact with each other during <style="Link"><link="lull-periods">Lull Periods</link></style>).

<style="Link"><link="backseat-gamers">Backseat Gamers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="friend-lists">Friend Lists</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-instance-duration">Negotiable Game Instance Duration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="synchronous-gameplay">Synchronous Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-strategy-identification">Team Strategy Identification</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tvt">TvT</link></style>

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Togetherness</style> increases the likelihood for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, it also makes it likely that players take upon themselves different <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>. In case where the players feeling [[Togetherness] engage in <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, this sense of <style="CurrentLink">Togetherness</style> makes it likely that they consider each others' perspective, i.e. engage in <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style>.

The focusing <style="CurrentLink">Togetherness</style> can have upon creating a sense of belonging to a group through gameplay lessens the importance of extra-game reasons to break apart that group. In this sense, [[Togetherness] works toward players having <style="Link"><link="actor-detachment">Actor Detachment</link></style> against each other.
